summary: About one - in - five police officers nationally ( 21 % ) say their job nearly always or often makes them feel angry and frustrated – feelings that are linked to more negative views toward the public . Frustration is more prevalent than anger among today ’s police officers . About half of the officers surveyed ( 51 % ) say their work nearly always ( 10 % ) or often ( 41 % ) makes them feel frustrated , while 22 % say they nearly always ( 3 % ) or often ( 19 % ) feel angry . When these two measures are combined , a total of 21 % of officers say they nearly always or often feel angry and frustrated . The survey finds that officers who frequently feel angry and frustrated by their job are twice as likely as all other police to say officers have reason to distrust most people ( 46 % vs. 23 % ) . They are more likely than their colleagues to agree that some people can only be brought to reason the hard , physical way ( 56 % vs. 41 % ) and to say they have become more callous toward people since taking this job ( 77 % vs. 50 % ) .
